required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Conversion of Seddon III Nerve Injury to Seddon I/II Nerve Injury
clinical_study.official_title: Conversion of Seddon III Nerve Injury to Seddon I/II Nerve Injury

brief_summary.textblock: This study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of PEG 3350 for use in nerve repair.

detailed_description.textblock:
To demonstrate more rapid and increased return of function by PEG-fusion compared to the best current nerve repair techniques. Neurorrhaphy is not new, being performed now for over 150 years much research has been performed. PEG-Axon fusion on the other hand is relatively new in mammals. Success has already been obtained by two institutions in the rat sciatic nerve transections, demonstrating rapid return of behavioral function4. These however are very controlled injuries and unclear how well these will translate into human studies. For this reason 3 separate clinical studies in increasing order of complexity are proposed.
The first study proposed will be PEG fusion in digital nerve lacerations. Two goals will be demonstrated; improved innervation density and improved innervation threshold compared to traditional repair, and complication rate similar or less than traditional repair. This will demonstrate the safety and efficacy of the procedure.

primary_outcome.measure: To demonstrate more rapid and increased return of function by PEG-fusion compared to the best current nerve repair techniques
primary_outcome.description: Three goals will be demonstrated; improved innervation density and improved innervation threshold compared to traditional repair, rapid return of motor function and complication rate similar or less than traditional repair. This will demonstrate the safety and efficacy of the procedure

clinical_study.condition: Injury of Other Nerves at Wrist and Hand Level of Unspecified Arm, Initial Encounter

arm_group.arm_group_label: Nerve injury to palm and fingers
arm_group.description: Adult patients with acute clean nerve transections of the higher arm injuries in the forearm, wrist, palm and digits of the hand will be recruited

intervention.description: Demonstrate more rapid and increased return of function by PEG-fusion compared to best current nerve repair techniques
intervention.arm_group_label: Nerve injury to palm and fingers

criteria.textblock:
- Only clean cut nerve transections of the higher arm injuries in the forearm, wrist, palm and digits of the hand will be included.
- Pregnant women cannot participate because of possible unknown and unpredictable risks to the unborn child.
- Patients with nerve injuries that result in segmental loss that cannot be repaired in a tension free manner will be excluded.
- Injuries beyond 24 hours will be excluded Patients with known G6PD deficiency
